Posts.Content: On Aug 29, 2015 1:03 AM dd6goldy wrote: I have been off of Arimidex for some time now and was placed on Letrozole generic for Femara.  I have had sever pain in my upper abdomen when ever I lay down or sit for any length of time.  Doctors can't find out what is wrong, in the mean time I am exausted because I sleep very little.  I never had this trouble before.  After I went through all the cancer treatment for breast cancer just one day I started with this pain.  Has anyone else experanced anything like this?   Does anyone know if it could be from the Letrozole.  Any ideas would be most appreacted. You can find the side effects of pretty much any medication by doing a Google search. Here's what came up when I entered "Side effects, Letrozole". It gave me a page for Femara, but aches and pains are certainly two of the side effects. So far, I haven't come across an Aromatase Inhibitor that DOESN'T have aches and pains as a side effect, although some women tolerate the drugs just fine. I heard just yesterday that roughly 30% of the women who take these meds suffer from side effects. If you decide to go off the medication, you wouldn't be the first. But if you decide to go off, you might want to look into alternatives such as Turmeric Paste, Iodine (www.breastcancerchoices.org), and Frankincense(!). There are plenty of alternatives to choose from. I chose the three just listed because the feel right for me, so going with your gut instinct is part of it. There's a good book on this called "Your Medical Mind". Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Aug 17, 2005 12:00 AM Rossy wrote: I'm new to this site but maybe this will be of interest to someone. I have been on Arimidex for almost 2 years now, having had a mastectomy in November 2003. Firstly I had hardly any side effects and slowly but surely they seem to be building up, some days far worse than the next. I have never had nausea though, thank goodness. The main side effects which I am experiencing now are aching bones and joints, mainly while trying to sleep at night. Also tiredness and seem to want to just go to bed to rest from as early as 8 in the evening - this is sad as I always went to bed late before my breast cancer. I also contemplated coming off the drug but decided that as the cancer hasn't come back at all in almost 2 years then perhaps I am doing the right thing in taking it every day. Your story, and the story of so many other posters here, is why I refused to take Arimidex and am approaching my treatment with lifestyle changes (diet & exercise mainly).  If you're considering going off it, you might find some of the links here to be of interest: https://www.facebook.com/BreastCancerBandits
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Sep 17, 2015 2:36 PM dixieEQ wrote: My onco sent me to a rheumatologist who prescribed Celebrex and Gabapentin.  That helped some but I found a lot of improvement by going on gluten free diet which I originally started to try and drop a few pounds.  I still have some pain but not enough to stay on heavy duty meds like Celebrex.  Some days I do resort to over the counter meds for the pain. My biggest issue at this point is the zombie fatigue syndrome (as I call it) and the depression that set in along with nausea, dizzyness, and unability to concentrate. However, it is discouraging to think my options were to either die of cancer or live with these gradually increasing side effects of the Arimidex that turn me into a depressed, decrepit old woman that the age of 57.  When prior to my diagnosis I was a very energetic, happy, active person with no indication of impending life altering disease creeping in.  Then I found that &*$%# lump. From some of the reading I've gone, there appears to be a connection between breast cancer and hypothroidism. Your fatigue and depression are symptoms of low thyroid. If you haven't had that checked, it might help.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: Your mom is experiencing known side-effects of Arimidex. There are several alternative "dietary" approaches to treatment. Your mom's sense of what her body needs and doesn't need is important when deciding what treatment course she should follow... along with the particulars of her cancer. I've had 3 primary breast cancers since 2000 (I'm now 63) and had radiation the first time. If I had to do it again, I'd skip all "standard" treatment other than surgery, and turn to a nutrient dense diet, as well as supplements through a Naturopathic Doctor, to strengthen my immune system.  Depending on how aggressive the tumor was, the likelihood of your mom having a recurrence is about 15% over the next 5 years. That means there's an 85% chance she'll never get another breast cancer — without any further treatment than surgery. It comes down to a choice between quality vs. quantity of life. If your mom's life is uncomfortable because of the side-effects she's experiencing, it seems reasonable for her to stop taking the drug and follow whatever diet makes the most sense to her. You might want to check out www.breastcancerchoices.org for info on a variety of treatment approaches being used by many women (and some men) who've opted not to follow the "standard of care". The upshot — IMO — is that your mom will be fine without the hormone blocker. But I refused to take it myself, so I'm biased.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Jul 07, 2014 1:14 PM AlliBK wrote: I never had any  gynecological issues up and until I began Tamoxifen. It was suggested to me to have my ovaries removed or just go ahead have a hysterectomy. That's more surgery!! I told my Gyno why fix something that's not broke.  We should be made aware of these issues prior to taking drugs, then we can go into  treatment with a full understanding not be scared out of our witts later believing if we don't tow the line something bad will happen! It's unfair to us to be put in a stustion that in either case might not be in our best interest. I have since found another GYN and he agreed to go into surgery may not be the best thing Surgery is not always necessary.  AlliBK, you make the very point that has driven so many women away from the "standard of care". Far too many doctors don't discuss the side effects of what they recommend for treatment (even worse, many aren't familiar with the side effects). In the end, it seems most wise to follow your gut instinct about what's right for YOUR body. There are several books on this subject, but one you might find interesting is called "Your Medical Mind". It's available at Amazon. Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: From what I've read, estrogen enters the body in different foods. Soy is a major "estrogen creator". Estrogen is stored in the body's fat, so if you've got fat to lose, it'd be good to lose that (not that I've succeeded myself)! Alcohol forces the liver to process alcohol first, so the estrogen from foods can go unprocessed and be released back into the body. So cooling it on alcohol is also wise (not that I've fully succeeded in that either!). Finally, estrogen isn't the only contributing factor to breast cancer. There are ER- breast cancers. So far, to my knowledge, no one has yet figured out what causes the different kinds of breast cancer. My opinion: do what feels right for you, and keep all your thoughts as possible as you can (your thoughts affect your cells). Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: There seems to be compelling evidence that curcumin can stop and/or reverse breast cancer. Curcumin is found in tumeric, and in also available in supplement form. As a 4 time breast cancer survivor (all of them different, so all of the "primary"), I take a supplement called Meriva, as well as a teaspoon of organic tumeric each day. The tumeric is available at your local health food store or from Amazon. It's oil soluable and needs a little help getting into the cells, so I take it mixed in some olive oil and with a pinch of fresh ground black pepper (reported to open the cancer cell walls). For a bit more info on tumeric, here's a link to a page with a lot of info: http://www.breastcancerchoices.org/curcumin.html If you're on Facebook, here's a page with many (MANY) posts about supplements and other approaches to cancer treatment / prevention (be sure to scroll!):  https://www.facebook.com/BreastCancerBandits I also take AHCC (a mushroom extract), Indolplex (helps regulate estrogen levels) and 5,000iu D3. If you haven't seen a Naturopathic Doctor, I highly recommend you do. A good one can get you on supplements and homeopathic treatments that could help. A well trained ND also offers acupuncture which (in my experience) works miracles for pain management and treatment of systemic issues.  IMO, more radiation to the hip and lower back runs a high risk of increasing cancer malignancy. Here's just one article on the subject: http://www.collective-evolution.com/2013/07/22/researchers-d The carrot juice recommendations are good, but as one poster put it, if it worked for everyone we'd have a whole lot more carrot crops. Here's an article on treating cancer with carrot juice:  http://www.naturalnews.com/042237_carrots_cancer_cure_vegeta Keeping positive thoughts, finding peace in your world (despite all reasons not to) really can help. Your thoughts truly do affect your body.  You've got a lot of support from so many others who've been down this road. You can do this!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: Seems you've found an approach that is most comfortable for you. I know these decisions are very difficult. My very best to you!
Posts.Title: Third lumpectomy

Posts.Content: On Jan 19, 2012 4:35 PM shirlrae wrote: I am curious as to why you would put yourself through this. I had a double mastectomy 2 years ago, I chose not to have reconstruction, but it is certainly available. Answering for me: I had originally decided to have a double mastectomy after my third diagnosis but I found myself waking in the middle of the night with sweaty hands, heart pounding, and in tears. This went on for several weeks until I decided to go with a lumpectomy instead. I slept just fine after that. I looked into reconstructive surgery (including meeting with the plastic surgeon) and ultimately opted against it when I read the potential side-effects, and stories of women living with them. I know my body well enough to be 99% certain that if it's "rare", it'll happen to me. I'm still experiencing fatigue from the radiation I got for my first breast cancer. It's like hitting a wall of sleepiness that sends me to bed for 8 hours or more. That first happened after my 2nd radiation treatment — when I had 31 more to go. Fatigue is a known side-effect of radiation while you're getting it, but it usually sets in toward the end of treatment. I got it early. The after effects I'm experiencing are, of course, rare. I learned from my first diagnosis (over 11 years ago) that my body is very loud at letting me know what it needs (and doesn't need). That's why I didn't get chemotherapy with any of my breast cancers. I researched it to make sure I wasn't letting emotion dictate my intellectual choices and it turned out that — for me — the "five-year disease-free survival" statistics haven't justified chemo. It's been 11 years and that breast cancer hasn't recurred, although two others have developed (the latest in the radiated breast). In other words, I'm dealing with my body as I've come to know it, and I'm at peace with my approach. There are no guarantees of disease free survival — even after a double mastectomy — so peace is a good place to land. After three distinctly different brease cancers, my focus is on quality, rather than quantity, of life. I realize I've taken a non-mainstream approach, but I also know I'm typically at the extreme of the bell curve... which is to say that what happens to me isn't what happens with the majorty of patients (even my doctors concur). I've come to accept this and am at peace with it as well.  Hope this helps ;)
Posts.Title: Third lumpectomy

Posts.Content: On Dec 20, 2011 4:26 PM Verna wrote: I have stage 1 grade 3 DIC.  Have had 2 lumpectomies with margins and additional lump.  Just completed 4 sessions of chemo and now my options are a third lumpectomy or mastectomy.  I am 76 years old.  Lymph nodes were good. Radiation would follow lumpectomy but not mastectomy. Having trouble deciding which way to go.  Has anyone had 3 lumpectomies?   Hi Verna, I had my third lumpectomy last September, with no additional treatment. The first was in 2000 (Stage 1, triple negative)... surgery followed by radiation. The latest was in the SAME previously radiated breast, but was a distinctly different type of breast cancer. In fact, all three lumpectomies have been to remove three different primary breast cancers. It's hard to tell from your post if you're experiencing on-going recurrences. If so, my input might not be as useful to you as you'd like. Treatment protocols for breast cancer have changed a lot over the last 5-6 years. I'm assuming you really mean DIC (and not DCIS). If it is an on-going recurrence, you've got an insistent cancer there. Even after a mastectomy, breast cancer can form on the chest where the breast was removed. Statistically, a lumpectomy + radiation is the same as a mastectomy. Both have side effects.  Given your age, some treatments (including chemo) can lose their efficacy. My recommendation is to ask your surgeon or oncologist for clinical trial study summaries on patients similar to you (in age, type of breast cancer, etc.), as information for you to consider as you make your decision. The summaries should give you an idea of what's worked best and for how long. Personally, at age 62, I've turned down additional treatment (post surgery) because the side effects would substantially impact my quality of life. But each of us is different, and you (like all of us) need to feel comfortable with your treatment decisions. If you haven't already moved forward, I wish you well with it. Here's a link to a Facebook page I've begun with some links that might be of interest to you: https://www.facebook.com/BreastCancerBandits
Posts.Title: Third lumpectomy

Posts.Content: On Jan 19, 2012 11:13 PM shirlrae wrote: You know your body and what is best for you as I do and that is why I had a double Mas. I so agree with you about the quality of life. I took myself off Arimidex a couple weeks ago. It is amazing how much better I feel. I gave it 2 years and couldn't face 3 more in such pain. Best wishes to you.  And back to you, Shirlrae. Despite the different approaches we all take, there's still a wonderful sense of sisterhood with fellow survivors. I don't know how long I'll last, but I DO know I'm going to live my life as normally, happily, and peacefully as I can for as long as I can. I turned down Arimidex before starting it because of the side effects. I already have osteoarthritis and aching joints... did I really want 5 more years of it, knowing that in the 6th year, the efficacy of Arimidex wears off? (BTW, there's a lot of research on foods that act as natural aromatase inhibitors. If you're a Facebook user, you might find some useful links at this page: https://www.facebook.com/BreastCancerBandits. My best to you, too. Robin
